Key Arguments: The author believes they do not need ACMA to protect them from misinformation, as they are capable of critically analyzing information themselves.
The bill is seen as inconsistent with basic human rights, particularly freedom of speech and expression.
The bill is considered ambiguous regarding the development and enforcement of misinformation codes.
The author argues that the bill grants ACMA excessive power without sufficient checks and balances.
The penalties proposed in the bill are viewed as heavy-handed and unconstitutional.
The author suggests that the bill should instead focus on regulating information from the government to the public.
Main Themes: Criticism of government handling of COVID-19 information
Notable Quotes: As an Australian citizen I do not need ACMA to ‘protect’ me, I am quite capable of choosing what information I read or watch, then critically analyse ideas for myself.
Reading through this bill I find it inconsistent with basic human rights of freedom of speech and expression.
This Bill allows ACMA too much power in deciding what is misinformation, without any meaningful checks and balances in place.
